As Your Highness is aware in most coutries births * \ and deaths are registered by the Government, which enables the authorities to know whother the population is increas ing or decreasing and in also an indication of the condi tion in different towns or parts of the country as it shows whether more people die in certain areas than i*i other areas. I suggest to Your Higimess that it would be most useful and desirable to introduce the registration of births and deaths in Bahrain. Setae years ago such a suggestion would have caused alarm and excitement but now T feel sure that people will understand that this action will assist the Government in arranging food supplies for the people of Bahrain and I believe the people will readily co-operate. Your Highness will remember the great difficulty which we had to overcome when we held the Census. The people now fully understand how useful the Census has been and I have been told even in the villages that everybody is now glad that the Government counted the people. I venture to remind Your Highness that it was I who suggested the Census and when I ^irst suggested it most people were not in favour of the suggestion. I now request Your Highness to approve of my suggestion that wo should consider ways of instituting the registra tion of births and deaths throughout Bahrain. Adviser. Dear Sir, We have been advised the United Kingdom Delegation to the United Nations that you would be kind enough to handle for the Statistical Office the distribut ion of the enclosed quenstionnaires which relate to demographic statistics in Bhutan, Bahrein Islands, Kuwait, Muscat and Oman, Qatar, and the Trucial Coast. The Population Commission of the United Nations has urged that the demographic statistics year book attempt to present statistics, especially population totals, for all areas of the world. The Statistical Office is fully aware of the complete lack of most of these data among nomadic peoples and in under-developed areas of the world generally. But nevertheless, we feel that it is preferable to have on file, in uniform table form, all such official data as ara- available, and we have, therefore, not prepared an abridged questionnaire which would summarize our ideas on what statistics might be available, nor have we limited the distribution of the questionnaire on the basis of presumed availability of data. I would appreciate it very much if you would be good enough to forward the questionnaires, together with the transmittal letters enclosed, tothe authorities who might be in a position to supply any estimates, at least those of total population. Need less to say I shall be most grateful for any assistance you can give us in this matter. Very truly yours, Sgd. William R. Leonard Acting Director Statistical Office. Yours ever, Agency. The Persian Gulf Residency, Bahrain. rCOPY E .36 (262/5/50) BRITISH RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN. 1st May 1950. Sir, I have the honour to forward herewith a report by the Bahrain Government on the census which they have recently held. The last census was held in 1941 when the figure for the total population was 89,970. The new figure is 109,650 showing an increase of nearly 20 , 000 , but it is probable that a number of people escaped the enumeration in 1941 as it was then feared that the census was intended as a basis for either conscrip tion or taxation. It is reckoned that about 6,000 persons, nearly all of them males normally resident in Bahrain were absent when the census was taken. The increase is almost entirely confined to the towns of Manama and Muharraq and must be accounted for in part by immigration. It will be seen from the report that the Bahrain Government are of opinion that there has been no drift from the villages to the tov/ns and that the high rate of infant mortality is responsible for the absence of any increase in the population of the villages. This may be the case but I rather suspect that a certain num ber of men from the villages have obtained employment in the towns and are now residing there. 2. The total European population including Americans but excluding ships 1 crews is now 1,683. Europeans were not sepa rately enumerated in 1941, but there must have been a substan tial increase. Persian subjects number 6,934 as against 7,547 in 1941 but it is probable that many have passed themselves off as Bahrain subjects. There are many persons of Persian origin who have in fact adopted Bahrain nationality and at a rough estimate I should place the total number of persons of Persian origin and still using the Persian tongue in Bahrain at 10,000. The number of Indians including Pakistanis, Anglo- Indians and Goanese has increased from 1 .424 to 3,043. This is a very substantial increase and affords some Justification for the restrictions which the Bahrain Government have asked us to impose on the immigration of Indians. 3. You will see from the statistics that 96/t of the popula tion are Muhammadans and that there are 2,932 Christians, 975 Hindus and 293 Jews. A large proportion of the Jews now propose to emigrate to Israel and the Bahrain Government are putting no obstacle in their way, but will not permit them to return. Amongst the Muhammadans the Sunnis and Shiahs were not separately enumerated. This was in order to avoid causing ill feeling between the two sects and because the Sunnis, to which sect the ruling family belongs, feared that the figures would show a Shiah majority as they did in 1941. when 46,354 Shiahs were enumerated as against 41,944 Sunnis. 4. There are about 7,500 more males than females and taking absentees into account the excess of males over females must be somewhere in the neighbourhood of 13,000. This dispropor tion between the sexes can be accounted for in great part by the large number of foreigners who have come to Bahrain for employment without bringing their families. There are no l2 7 ' i ' occupational statistics but it is interesting to note that about 10 ^ of the indigenous population have been recorded as literate. There is no definition of what is meant by ’literacy* but it must be assumed that the vast majority of those recorded as literate have not been educated beyond the primary standard. 5. I am sending copies of this despatch to the British Middle East Office and the Tehran Embassy. I have the honour to be, with the highest respect, Sir, Your most obedient Servant, 3d. W.R. physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 113; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 5-49; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence related to the Bahrain censuses of 1941 and 1950. The majority of the correspondence is between the Political Agency in Bahrain, the Political Residency in the Persian Gulf at Bushire, and the Adviser to the Government of Bahrain (Charles Dalrymple Belgrave).Included in the file is the following:correspondence from various departments and offices of the Government of India (Central Publication Branch in Delhi, External Affairs Department, Development Department in Northwest Frontier Province, Governor General in Baluchistan) regarding the procedures required for holding a census;correspondence and public notices from the Government of Bahrain concerning the dates and procedures for each census;requests from the Adviser, Belgrave, for census forms to be completed for staff at the Political Agency (some forms present within the file, folios 74-76);requests for demographic statistics from various offices and institutions, including the United Nations Statistical Office in New York, the World Health Organization in Singapore, and the United States Vice Consulate in Dhahran.Folios 102-112 are internal office notes.
